title: Layoff Survival Calculator
description: Calculate your financial runway and determine how long you can survive without a regular paycheck.
methodSummary: Total Monthly Burn = Basic Expenses + Debt Payments.
assumptions: Unemployment benefits are assumed to last for 6 months.
Assumes no further reductions in expenses during the layoff period.
Assumes immediate availability of liquid savings.
insights: High-interest debt is the biggest threat to your survival runway during a layoff.
The first 30 days are critical for 'trimming the fat' from your monthly expenses to extend your buffer.

faqs.q: What is a safe risk level?
faqs.a: A 'Low' risk level corresponds to having 12+ months of runway. 'Critical' is anything under 3 months.

faqs.q: Should I use severance net or gross?
faqs.a: Always use net (after-tax) severance, as that is the actual cash available to pay your bills.

faqs.q: How do debt payments affect runway?
faqs.a: Debts are fixed costs. Unlike food or subscriptions, they are harder to reduce, making them high-impact on your survival.
6 months is the standard duration in many jurisdictions. If yours differs, adjust the monthly amount to match your total expected benefit.

faqs.q: Should I pay off debt during a layoff threat?
faqs.a: Liquid cash is usually more valuable than debt reduction during a layoff, as it provides flexibility for essential survival costs.

faqs.q: What if I find a job sooner?
faqs.a: The calculator represents your 'worst-case' runway. Finding a job sooner shifts your status back to 'Career Choice' vs 'Survival'.
